Curve Fitting#

Code for fitting data to curves

class eosdxanalysis.models.curve_fitting.GaussianDecomposition(image=None, p0_dict=None, p_lower_bounds_dict=None, p_upper_bounds_dict=None)#

Class for decomposing keratin diffraction patterns as a sum of Gaussians with angular spread.

best_fit(image)#

Use scipy.optimize.curve_fit to decompose a keratin diffraction pattern into a sum of Gaussians with angular spread.

Function to optimize: self.keratin_function

estimate_parameters(image=None, width=4, position_tol=0.2)#

Estimate Gaussian fit parameters based on provided image

image : can be None, pulled from init width : averaging width used to produce 1D profiles position_tol : factor used to check if detected peak locations are incorrect

(p0_dict, p_lower_bounds_dict, p_upper_bounds_dict): tuple

Also stores these parameters in class parameters.

Notes: - Use horizontal and vertical radial intensity profiles, and their differences,

to calculate properties of isotropic and anisotropic Gaussians.

  • The 9A and 5A peaks are hypothesized to be the sum of isotropic and anisotropic Gaussians

  • The 5-4A ring and background intensities are hypothesized to be isotropic Gaussians

  • That makes a total of 6 Gaussians

fit_error(image, fit)#

Returns the square error between a function and its approximation.

gen_meshgrid(shape)#

Generate a meshgrid

keratin_function(polar_point, peak_location_radius_9A, peak_std_9A, peak_amplitude_9A, cos_power_9A, peak_location_radius_5A, peak_std_5A, peak_amplitude_5A, cos_power_5A, peak_location_radius_5_4A, peak_std_5_4A, peak_amplitude_5_4A, peak_std_bg, peak_amplitude_bg)#

Generate entire kertain diffraction pattern at the points (r, theta), with 16 parameters as the arguements to 4 calls of radial_gaussian.

Parameters:

polar_point (tuple) – (r, theta) where r and theta are a meshgrid

p0 … p15: parameters to 4 radial_gaussians. Each 4 parameters are peak_location, peak_width, peak_amplitude, and angular spread.

Returns a contiguous flattened array suitable for use with scipy.optimize.curve_fit.

objective(p, image, r, theta)#

Generate a keratin diffraction pattern with the given parameters list p and return the fit error

parameter_init(image=None, p0_dict=None, p_lower_bounds_dict=None, p_upper_bounds_dict=None)#

P parameters: - peak_radius - width - amplitude

radial_gaussian(r, theta, peak_radius, peak_angle, peak_std, peak_amplitude, arc_angle, resolution=(512, 512))#

Isotropic and radial Gaussian

Currently uses convolution with a high-resolution arc specified by arc-angle. Future will possibly use analytic expression for convolution of a Gaussian with an arc. Assumes quadrant-fold symmetry. Assumes standard deviation is the same for x and y directions.

Parameters:

  • r (array_like) – Polar point radius to evaluate function at (r must be same shape as theta)

  • theta (array_like) – Polar point angle to evaluate function at (r must be same shape as theta)

  • peak_radius (float) – Location of the Gaussian peak from the center

  • peak_angle (float) – 0 or np.pi/2 to signify equatorial or meridional peak location (respectively)

  • peak_std (float) – Gaussian standard deviation

  • peak_amplitude (float) – Gaussian peak amplitude

  • arc_angle (float) – arc angle in radians, 0 is anisotropic, pi is fully isotropic

Returns:

Value of Gaussian function at polar input points (r, theta)

Return type:

array_like (same shape as r and theta)

class eosdxanalysis.models.curve_fitting.PolynomialFit#

Class for polynomial fitting

classmethod fit_poly(input_points, outputs, degree=2)#

Given inputs, outputs, and polynomial degree, perform a linear regression. If input_points are multidimensional, then polynomial will be multidimensional. For example, 2D will have x, y, x*y, x^2, etc.
